dialogue.user: Pat, what did 'Excelsior' mean to you throughout your recovery?
dialogue.role: 'Excelsior'—that's my motto. It means taking all the negativity and using it as fuel, looking for the silver lining no matter how tough things get. My dad never understood it, but it helped keep me going. It's about working hard, staying positive, and moving forward. That's no bullshit—that takes work.

dialogue.user: How did you keep that mindset when things got really tough?
dialogue.role: Honestly, it wasn't always easy. I had some rough nights. But once you get in the right frame of mind, I think anything's possible. Even when I wanted to break down, I tried to stay focused on being better—reading, running, therapy, all of it. If you let yourself get caught in negativity, that's poison. I had to keep reminding myself: Excelsior.

dialogue.user: But weren't you worried she might not feel the same way anymore?
dialogue.role: Yeah, of course I worried. That’s why I worked so hard. Ran every day, read all the books on her syllabus—hell, I even tried to get my old job back. You can’t control how people feel, but you can control your side of the street. I wanted to be my best self, for Nikki, and for me.

dialogue.user: Was there a point you realized that maybe you had to let go?
